Trellis Output

Source: vignettes/trellis-output.Rmd
trellis-output.Rmd

Here is an example to output plot in ggplot2 into trellis. The example in plotly can be found in vignette “Plots in plotly”. We will also show

library(DCVtestkit)

# Data Creation

dilution_percent <- c(
  10, 20, 25, 40, 50, 60,
  75, 80, 100, 125, 150,
  10, 25, 40, 50, 60,
  75, 80, 100, 125, 150
)

dilution_batch_name <- c(
  "B1", "B1", "B1", "B1", "B1",
  "B1", "B1", "B1", "B1", "B1", "B1",
  "B2", "B2", "B2", "B2", "B2",
  "B2", "B2", "B2", "B2", "B2"
)

sample_name <- c(
  "Sample_010a", "Sample_020a",
  "Sample_025a", "Sample_040a", "Sample_050a",
  "Sample_060a", "Sample_075a", "Sample_080a",
  "Sample_100a", "Sample_125a", "Sample_150a",
  "Sample_010b", "Sample_025b",
  "Sample_040b", "Sample_050b", "Sample_060b",
  "Sample_075b", "Sample_080b", "Sample_100b",
  "Sample_125b", "Sample_150b"
)

lipid1_area_saturated <- c(
  5748124, 16616414, 21702718, 36191617,
  49324541, 55618266, 66947588, 74964771,
  75438063, 91770737, 94692060,
  5192648, 16594991, 32507833, 46499896,
  55388856, 62505210, 62778078, 72158161,
  78044338, 86158414
)

lipid2_area_linear <- c(
  31538, 53709, 69990, 101977, 146436, 180960,
  232881, 283780, 298289, 344519, 430432,
  25463, 63387, 90624, 131274, 138069,
  205353, 202407, 260205, 292257, 367924
)

lipid3_area_lod <- c(
  544, 397, 829, 1437, 1808, 2231,
  3343, 2915, 5268, 8031, 11045,
  500, 903, 1267, 2031, 2100,
  3563, 4500, 5300, 8500, 10430
)

lipid4_area_nonlinear <- c(
  380519, 485372, 478770, 474467, 531640, 576301,
  501068, 550201, 515110, 499543, 474745,
  197417, 322846, 478398, 423174, 418577,
  426089, 413292, 450190, 415309, 457618
)

dilution_annot <- tibble::tibble(
  Sample_Name = sample_name,
  Dilution_Batch_Name = dilution_batch_name,
  Dilution_Percent = dilution_percent
)

lipid_data <- tibble::tibble(
  Sample_Name = sample_name,
  Lipid1 = lipid1_area_saturated,
  Lipid2 = lipid2_area_linear,
  Lipid3 = lipid3_area_lod,
  Lipid4 = lipid4_area_nonlinear
)

dilution_table <- create_dilution_table(
  dilution_annot = dilution_annot,
  lipid_data_wide = lipid_data,
  common_column = "Sample_Name",
  signal_var = "Area",
  column_group = "Transition_Name"
)

dilution_classified <- dilution_table %>%
  summarise_dilution_table(
    grouping_variable = c(
      "Transition_Name",
      "Dilution_Batch_Name"
    ),
    conc_var = "Dilution_Percent",
    signal_var = "Area"
  ) %>%
  dplyr::arrange(.data$Transition_Name) %>%
  evaluate_linearity(grouping_variable = c(
    "Transition_Name",
    "Dilution_Batch_Name"
  ))

Here is the output of dilution_table and dilution_classified

print(head(dilution_table), width = 100)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 5
#>   Sample_Name Dilution_Batch_Name Dilution_Percent Transition_Name     Area
#>   <chr>       <chr>                          <dbl> <chr>              <dbl>
#> 1 Sample_010a B1                                10 Lipid1           5748124
#> 2 Sample_010a B1                                10 Lipid2             31538
#> 3 Sample_010a B1                                10 Lipid3               544
#> 4 Sample_010a B1                                10 Lipid4            380519
#> 5 Sample_020a B1                                20 Lipid1          16616414
#> 6 Sample_020a B1                                20 Lipid2             53709
print(head(dilution_classified), width = 100)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 11
#>   Transition_Name Dilution_Batch_Name wf1_group      wf2_group      r_corr
#>   <chr>           <chr>               <chr>          <chr>           <dbl>
#> 1 Lipid1          B1                  Poor Linearity Saturation      0.963
#> 2 Lipid1          B2                  Poor Linearity Saturation      0.950
#> 3 Lipid2          B1                  Good Linearity Good Linearity  0.990
#> 4 Lipid2          B2                  Good Linearity Good Linearity  0.995
#> 5 Lipid3          B1                  Poor Linearity LOD             0.964
#> 6 Lipid3          B2                  Poor Linearity LOD             0.978
#>   pra_linear mandel_p_val concavity r2_linear r2_adj_linear mandel_stats
#>        <dbl>        <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>         <dbl>        <dbl>
#> 1       70.5   0.0000297  -4174.        0.928         0.920       71.2  
#> 2       62.3   0.000166   -4137.        0.903         0.890       52.9  
#> 3       92.8   0.150         -4.91      0.980         0.978        2.53 
#> 4       94.3   0.382         -1.94      0.990         0.988        0.868
#> 5       71.2   0.00000678     0.468     0.930         0.922      106.   
#> 6       74.7   0.00256        0.321     0.956         0.951       20.9

We then create the ggplot plots with dilution_table and dilution_classified

# Create a trellis table
trellis_table_orig <- add_ggplot_panel(
  dilution_table = dilution_table,
  dilution_summary = dilution_classified,
  grouping_variable = c(
    "Transition_Name",
    "Dilution_Batch_Name"
  ),
  dil_batch_var = "Dilution_Batch_Name",
  dil_batch_col = c(
    "#377eb8",
    "#4daf4a"
  ),
  conc_var = "Dilution_Percent",
  conc_var_units = "%",
  conc_var_interval = 50,
  signal_var = "Area",
  plot_first_half_lin_reg = FALSE
)

trellis_list_orig <- trellis_table_orig$panel

To output these plots as a trellis in html, convert the grouping_variable as conditional variable, the column holding the plots as a panel_variable and the other columns as common cognostics.

We use the function convert_to_cog which uses the default cog_df created by create_default_cog_df.

create_default_cog_df()
#>             col_name_vec                                    desc_vec type_vec
#> 1        Transition_Name                             Transition_Name   factor
#> 2    Dilution_Batch_Name                         Dilution_Batch_Name   factor
#> 3  Transition_Name_Class                      Classes of Transitions   factor
#> 4              wf1_group                       Group from workflow 1   factor
#> 5              wf2_group                       Group from workflow 2   factor
#> 6                 r_corr                Pearson Correlation R values  numeric
#> 7             pra_linear Linear Regression Percent Residual Accuracy  numeric
#> 8           mandel_p_val                    P values for Mandel test  numeric
#> 9              r2_linear                 Linear Regression R^2 Value  numeric
#> 10         r2_adj_linear        Linear Regression Adjusted R^2 Value  numeric
#> 11          mandel_stats             Test statistics for Mandel Test  numeric
#> 12             adl_value            Average Deviation from Linearity  numeric

Using the function convert_to_cog,

trellis_table_convert <- trellis_table_orig %>%
  convert_to_cog(
    grouping_variable = c(
      "Transition_Name",
      "Dilution_Batch_Name"
    ),
    panel_variable = "panel"
  )

The output is as follows.

print(head(trellis_table_convert), width = 100)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 12
#>   Transition_Name Dilution_Batch_Name wf1_group      wf2_g…¹ r_corr   pra_linear
#>   <cog>           <cog>               <cog>          <cog>   <cog>    <cog>     
#> 1 Lipid1          B1                  Poor Linearity Satura… 0.963362   70.49412
#> 2 Lipid2          B1                  Good Linearity Good L… 0.989903   92.75456
#> 3 Lipid3          B1                  Poor Linearity LOD     0.964252   71.18372
#> 4 Lipid4          B1                  Poor Linearity Poor L… 0.311458 -251.44937
#> 5 Lipid1          B2                  Poor Linearity Satura… 0.950007   62.30351
#> 6 Lipid2          B2                  Good Linearity Good L… 0.994815   94.32046
#>   mandel_p_val concavity     r2_linear r2_adj_linear mandel_stats panel     
#>   <cog>        <cog>         <cog>     <cog>         <cog>        <trllscp_>
#> 1 2.968599e-05 -4174.1333061 0.928067   0.920074      71.2051525  <patchwrk>
#> 2 1.501138e-01    -4.9071785 0.979908   0.977675       2.5335524  <patchwrk>
#> 3 6.775079e-06     0.4677827 0.929783   0.921981     106.2121740  <patchwrk>

#> 6 3.824145e-01    -1.9381407 0.989657   0.988364       0.8684023  <patchwrk>
#> # … with abbreviated variable name ¹​wf2_group

Observe that the attributes of the columns are different. For the grouping variable column labelled we have

print(attributes(trellis_table_convert$Transition_Name))
#> $cog_attrs
#> $cog_attrs$desc
#> [1] "conditioning variable"
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$type
#> [1] "factor"
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$group
#> [1] "condVar"
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$defLabel
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$defActive
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$filterable
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$log
#> [1] NA
#> 
#> 
#> $class
#> [1] "cog"       "character"

For the column labelled as a panel_variable, we have

print(attributes(trellis_table_convert$panel))
#> $class
#> [1] "trelliscope_panels" "list"

For the rest of the column converted to a common cognostics, we have

print(attributes(trellis_table_convert$r_corr))
#> $cog_attrs
#> $cog_attrs$desc
#> [1] "Pearson Correlation R values"
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$type
#> [1] "numeric"
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$group
#> [1] "common"
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$defLabel
#> [1] FALSE
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$defActive
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$filterable
#> [1] TRUE
#> 
#> $cog_attrs$log
#> [1] NA
#> 
#> 
#> $class
#> [1] "cog"     "numeric"

It is also possible for users to create their own cognostics as well.

transition_name <- c("Lipid1", "Lipid2", "Lipid3", "Lipid4")
transition_class <- c("Class1", "Class1", "Class2", "Class2")
transition_species <- c("SpeciesA", "SpeciesA", "SpeciesB", "SpeciesB")

transition_annot <- tibble::tibble(
  Transition_Name = transition_name,
  Transition_Class = transition_class,
  Transition_Species = transition_species
)


col_name_vec <- c("Transition_Name", "Transition_Class", "Transition_Species")
desc_vec <- c(
  "Names of Transitions",
  "Classes of Transitions",
  "Species of Transitions"
)

type_vec <- c("factor", "factor", "factor")

cog_df <- data.frame(
  col_name_vec = col_name_vec,
  desc_vec = desc_vec,
  type_vec = type_vec
)


trellis_table_orig_converted <- trellis_table_orig %>%
  dplyr::left_join(transition_annot, by = "Transition_Name") %>%
  convert_to_cog(
    cog_df = cog_df,
    grouping_variable = c(
      col_name_vec,
      "Dilution_Batch_Name"
    ),
    panel_variable = "panel",
    col_name_vec = "col_name_vec",
    desc_vec = "desc_vec",
    type_vec = "type_vec"
  )

The list of ggplots can be output as follows by calling this command in the R console:

view_trellis_html(
  trellis_table = trellis_table_orig_converted,
  grouping_variable = c(
    col_name_vec,
    "Dilution_Batch_Name"
  ),
  trellis_report_name = "Dilution_Plot",
  trellis_report_folder = "Dilution_Plot_Folder"
)

This will create a folder called “Dilution_Plot_Folder” as defined by trellis_report_folder in your current working directory.

You may view the plots by clicking on “index.html”
